com.gl.vn.me.ko.sample.instrumentation.util

Class AbstractClassFileTransformer

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.gl.vn.me.ko.sample.instrumentation.util.AbstractClassFileTransformer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ClassFileTransformer
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ClassFileTransformerExampleA, ClassFileTransformerExampleB, ClassFileTransformerExampleC, ClassFileTransformerExampleD

    public abstract class AbstractClassFileTransformer
extends Object
implements ClassFileTransformer
    Provides an ability to transform class files. See methods transform(ClassLoader, String, Class, ProtectionDomain, byte[]) and doTransform(CtClass) for details.

    Derived classes must be thread save.

    Instantiability: allowed from inside the derived class.
    Mutability: this class itself has nothing that can cause mutability; depends on the implementation of derived class.
    Thread safety: this class itself has nothing that can cause thread unsafety. Implementations of derived classes must be thread-safe.
    Cloneability: cloning is not forbidden; depends on the implementation of derived class.
    Serializability: serialization is not forbidden; depends on the implementation of derived class.

    • Method Detail

      • transform

        @Nullable
public final byte[] transform(@Nullable
                                        ClassLoader classLoader,
                                        String className,
                                        @Nullable
                                        Class<?> classBeingRedefined,
                                        ProtectionDomain protectionDomain,
                                        byte[] classfileBuffer)
                                 throws IllegalClassFormatException
        Transforms the supplied class file and returns a new replacement class file. This method invokes method doTransform(CtClass).

        Once a transformer has been registered with Instrumentation.addTransformer(ClassFileTransformer), the method will be called for every new class definition and every class redefinition. The request for a new class definition is made with one of ClassLoader.defineClass(...) methods. The request for a class redefinition is made with Instrumentation.redefineClasses(ClassDefinition[]) or its native equivalents. The transformer is called during the processing of the request, before the class file bytes have been verified or applied.

        While it's possible to create situations where method will be called concurrently for the same class, such situations must be avoided because they can lead to unpredictable results. Concurrent invocations for different classes are allowed and correct.

        The method returns null if no transformation is needed, otherwise it returns an array of bytes in class file format as specified in "The Java Virtual Machine Specification".

        Specified by:
        transform in interface ClassFileTransformer
        Parameters:
        classLoader - The defining loader of the class to be transformed, may be null if the bootstrap loader.
        className - The name of the class in the internal form of fully qualified class and interface names as defined in "The Java Virtual Machine Specification". For example: "java/lang/Object".
        classBeingRedefined - If this is a redefine, the class being redefined, otherwise null.
        protectionDomain - The protection domain of the class being defined or redefined. Actually the parameter is not used in this implementation.
        classfileBuffer - The input byte buffer in class file format (stays unmodified). Actually the parameter is not used in this implementation, because class file is obtained via Javassist framework from ClassPool. So if one want to chain transformations of the same class, one should use the same instance of CtClass obtained from the same ClassPool instance.
        Returns:
        A well-formed class file buffer (the result of the transform), or null if no transform is performed.
        Throws:
        IllegalClassFormatException - If the input does not represent a well-formed class file. Actually classfileBuffer argument is not used by this implementation so the method will newer throw an IllegalClassFormatException.
        See Also:
        ClassFileTransformer.transform(ClassLoader, String, Class, ProtectionDomain, byte[]), doTransform(CtClass)

      • acceptClassForTransformation

        protected abstract boolean acceptClassForTransformation(@Nullable
                                                        ClassLoader classLoader,
                                                        String className)
        An implementation of the method must decide whether the class can be transformed or not. If the method return true, transformer will try to obtain corresponded CtClass object from the ClassPool and if succeed the method doTransform(CtClass) will be called.
        Parameters:
        classLoader - The defining loader of the class to be transformed. Can be null if the bootstrap loader.
        className - The name of the class in the internal form of fully qualified class and interface names as defined in "The Java Virtual Machine Specification". For example: "java/lang/Object".
        Returns:
        • true if the class should be transformed.
        • false if the class must be skipped without any transformations applied.
        See Also:
        doTransform(CtClass)

      • doTransform

        @Nullable
protected abstract byte[] doTransform(CtClass ctClass)
                                         throws Exception
        An implementation of this method may transform the supplied class and return an array of transformed bytes in class file format as specified in "The Java Virtual Machine Specification". This method is called from method transform(ClassLoader, String, Class, ProtectionDomain, byte[]) for any invocation of the method except when class can't pass the filter (see acceptClassForTransformation(ClassLoader, String)) or {link javassist.CtClass} object can't be obtained from the ClassPool.

        Remember that once bytes were obtained from CtClass object (see JavassistEnvironment.getCtBytes(CtClass) method), the object becomes frozen and the next time one want to modify it, one should defrost the object (see CtClass.isFrozen() and CtClass.defrost() methods).

        Implementation of this method must synchronize access to the supplied instance of CtClass, because CtClass is not thread-safe and the method transform(ClassLoader, String, Class, ProtectionDomain, byte[]) can be called concurrently.

        Parameters:
        ctClass - Object that represents class file of a class to be transformed.
        Returns:
        An array of bytes in class file format (the result of the transform), or null if no transform was performed.
        Throws:
        Exception - If something goes wrong.
        See Also:
        acceptClassForTransformation(ClassLoader, String), transform(ClassLoader, String, Class, ProtectionDomain, byte[])
